Context:
This table is about the section 6.1 DOE > 6.1.3 DOE Method s > 6.1.3.1 Factorial Design. 
Title: 2-level fractional design (default generators) are used for full factorial and fractional factorial design.
Select 2-Level Factorial Design (Default Generators) as follows.
[image:rId15] 
Rows: row 1, column 1 = Introduction to the experiment This experiment is conducted to improve the yield of a specific reaction process. factor A is the reaction time, factor B is the reaction temperature, and factor C is the amount of ingredient. The specific experimental conditions are as follows. Reaction Time(A):    A0 =4, A1 =5(hour)A0 =4, A1 =5(시간) Reaction Temperature(B):    B0 =250, B1 =300(℃)B0 =250, B1 =300(℃) Amount of Ingredient(C):    C0 =3.0, C1 =3.5(g)C0 =3.0, C1 =3.5 (g) At this time, we cannot complete the experiment in one day, so we would like to experiment by confounding the interaction ABC with the day.
table_html: Introduction to the experiment This experiment is conducted to improve the yield of a specific reaction process. factor A is the reaction time, factor B is the reaction temperature, and factor C is the amount of ingredient. The specific experimental conditions are as follows. Reaction Time(A): A0 =4, A1 =5(hour)A0 =4, A1 =5(시간) Reaction Temperature(B): B0 =250, B1 =300(℃)B0 =250, B1 =300(℃) Amount of Ingredient(C): C0 =3.0, C1 =3.5(g)C0 =3.0, C1 =3.5 (g) At this time, we cannot complete the experiment in one day, so we would like to experiment by confounding the interaction ABC with the day.

This table is about the section 6.1 DOE > 6.1.3 DOE Method s > 6.1.3.1 Factorial Design. 
Title: General Full Factorial Design overcomes the limitation that the previous three designs (2-Level Factorial Design (Default Generators), 2-Level Factorial Design (Specified Generators), and Plackett-Burman Design) can only conduct 2-level experiments. DOE is capable of. The level of each factor can have any value. For example, when the number of factors is 3, the number of levels can be 2, 3, and 4, respectively. In General, Full Factorial Design, all possible combinations are tested, so if the number of levels is 2, 3, or 4, you will get the following design table.
The following is a Full Factorial Design 
Rows: row 1, column 1 = A; row 1, column 2 = B; row 1, column 3 = C; row 2, column 1 = 1; row 2, column 2 = 1; row 2, column 3 = 1; row 3, column 1 = 2; row 3, column 2 = 1; row 3, column 3 = 1; row 4, column 1 = 1; row 4, column 2 = 2; row 4, column 3 = 1; row 5, column 1 = 2; row 5, column 2 = 2; row 5, column 3 = 1

This table is about the section 6.1 DOE > 6.1.3 DOE Method s > 6.1.3.2.1 Central Composite Design. 
Rows: row 1, column 1 = Introduction to Experiments This experiment is an example of the application of the response surface experimental design method conducted by a tire company in 1979 to improve the driving performance of Monopoly radial tires. This is an experiment in which the amount of G300 and amount of V130 affect the response values of adhesion, modulus, and elongation.
table_html: Introduction to Experiments This experiment is an example of the application of the response surface experimental design method conducted by a tire company in 1979 to improve the driving performance of Monopoly radial tires. This is an experiment in which the amount of G300 and amount of V130 affect the response values of adhesion, modulus, and elongation.

This table is about the section 6.1 DOE > 6.1.3 DOE Method s > 6.1.3.3 Mixture Design. 
Rows: row 1, column 1 = Introduction to experiments In this experiment, we investigate the extent to which three components affect the firmness of the response product. The components have default values (0,1) without any special upper or lower limit conditions, and the experimenter tries to find out how each component affects the response value.
table_html: Introduction to experiments In this experiment, we investigate the extent to which three components affect the firmness of the response product. The components have default values (0,1) without any special upper or lower limit conditions, and the experimenter tries to find out how each component affects the response value.

This table is about the section 6.1 DOE > 6.1.3 DOE Method s > 6.1.3.3 Mixture Design. 
Title: Through Step 5 of Mixture Design, you can view surface plots and contour plots, and perform response optimizer tailored to the user's purpose. Below are the surface plot and contour plot for the Regression Model created in Step 4. 
Rows: row 1, column 1 = [image:rId94]; row 1, column 2 = [image:rId95]

This table is about the section 6.1 DOE > 6.1.3 DOE Method s > 6.1.3.3 Mixture Design. 
Title: If the goal is to conduct an experiment in a simplex region and create a regression model based on the experiment results, it would be desirable for the experiment points to be evenly distributed throughout the simplex region. The design that meets this purpose is Simplex Lattice Design. Simplex Lattice Design is a useful design for fitting m-order polynomials when there are n components.
Through Simplex Lattice Design, we will explain mixture volume design. First, select Simplex Lattice Design.
[image:rId98] 
Rows: row 1, column 1 = Introduction to experiments It is said that the strength of a metal is affected not only by the ratio but also by the amount of its components. Then, simply looking at the proportions of the components does not reveal the relationship between the components and the strength of the metal. Therefore, a mixture volume design can be used that can be used in these situations.
table_html: Introduction to experiments It is said that the strength of a metal is affected not only by the ratio but also by the amount of its components. Then, simply looking at the proportions of the components does not reveal the relationship between the components and the strength of the metal. Therefore, a mixture volume design can be used that can be used in these situations.

Context:
This table is about the section 6.1 DOE > 6.1.3 DOE Method s > 6.1.3.3 Mixture Design. 
Title: In this step, the regression model created in Step 4 is expressed as a surface plot and contour plot, and a response optimizer function is provided to meet the experimenter's purpose. When the amount of mixture is 2, the plot looks like this. 
Rows: row 1, column 1 = [image:rId103]; row 1, column 2 = [image:rId104]

This table is about the section 6.1 DOE > 6.1.3 DOE Method s > 6.1.3.3 Mixture Design. 
Rows: row 1, column 1 = Introduction to experiments This experiment aims to find out the relationship between three ingredients and how process variables (working temperature) affect the quality of the product. At this time, the limiting conditions for the three ingredients are as follows. 0.1≤ x1 ≤0.8,  0.0≤ x2 ≤0.6,  0.0≤ x3 ≤0.5
table_html: Introduction to experiments This experiment aims to find out the relationship between three ingredients and how process variables (working temperature) affect the quality of the product. At this time, the limiting conditions for the three ingredients are as follows. 0.1≤ x1 ≤0.8, 0.0≤ x2 ≤0.6, 0.0≤ x3 ≤0.5

This table is about the section 6.1 DOE > 6.1.3 DOE Method s > 6.1.3.4 Taguchi Design. 
Title: 2-Level Design is a design used when there are two levels per factor. It is said that there is an experiment as follows.
Select Taguchi 2-Level Design.
[image:rId124] 
Rows: row 1, column 1 = Introduction to experiments In order to reduce the amount of CO in the exhaust gas, the related factors A-H are arranged in an orthogonal array table, and the noise factors are used to generate the minimum CO when driven in a certain way on three types of roads (R1, R2, and R3). Find the conditions.
table_html: Introduction to experiments In order to reduce the amount of CO in the exhaust gas, the related factors A-H are arranged in an orthogonal array table, and the noise factors are used to generate the minimum CO when driven in a certain way on three types of roads (R1, R2, and R3). Find the conditions.

Context:
This table is about the section 6.1 DOE > 6.1.3 DOE Method s > 6.1.3.4 Taguchi Design. 
Title: 3-Level Design is a design used when there are three levels per factor. Suppose we have the following experiment.
Select Taguchi Design 3-Level Design.
[image:rId130] 
Rows: row 1, column 1 = Introduction to experiments A chemical company that produces a certain resin wants to conduct an experiment to reduce the content of impurities contained in this resin. The upper limit of the specification is 4.0%, and if this specification is not met, a loss of 50,000 won per 10 kg occurs. Four control factors expected to affect impurities were taken as follows. A : Bond mixing ratio level 3 A0, A1, A2 B : Bonding method level 3 (B0, B1, B2) C : Surface treatment method level 3 C0, C1, C2 D : Heat treatment method level 3 D0, D1, D2 As a non-controlling factor U : 2nd level of worker(unskilled worker, skilled worker) V : Resin production line level 2 was selected and the produced resin was analyzed in the laboratory to obtain the content of impurities.
table_html: Introduction to experiments A chemical company that produces a certain resin wants to conduct an experiment to reduce the content of impurities contained in this resin. The upper limit of the specification is 4.0%, and if this specification is not met, a loss of 50,000 won per 10 kg occurs. Four control factors expected to affect impurities were taken as follows. A : Bond mixing ratio level 3 A0, A1, A2 B : Bonding method level 3 (B0, B1, B2) C : Surface treatment method level 3 C0, C1, C2 D : Heat treatment method level 3 D0, D1, D2 As a non-controlling factor U : 2nd level of worker(unskilled worker, skilled worker) V : Resin production line level 2 was selected and the produced resin was analyzed in the laboratory to obtain the content of impurities.

Context:

Rows: row 1, column 1 = Types of characteristic values; row 1, column 2 = Loss function of one data y; row 1, column 3 = Average loss function when n pieces of data are obtained; row 1, column 4 = SN ratio; row 2, column 1 = nominal the best characteristics; row 2, column 2 = A Δ2 y-m2; row 2, column 3 = A Δ21 n i=1 n y i -m2; row 2, column 4 = 10 log1 n S m -V V =20 log y s; row 3, column 1 = the smaller the better characteristics; row 3, column 2 = A Δ2 y2; row 3, column 3 = A Δ21 n i=1 n y i2; row 3, column 4 = -10 log1 n i=1 n y i2; row 4, column 1 = large the better characteristics; row 4, column 2 = A Δ21 y2; row 4, column 3 = A Δ21 n i=1 n1 y i2; row 4, column 4 = -10 log1 n i=1 n1 y i2
table_html:
Types of characteristic values Loss function of one data y Average loss function when n pieces of data are obtained SN ratio
nominal the best characteristics A Δ2 y-m2 A Δ21 n i=1 n y i -m2 10 log1 n S m -V V =20 log y s
the smaller the better characteristics A Δ2 y2 A Δ21 n i=1 n y i2 -10 log1 n i=1 n y i2
large the better characteristics A Δ21 y2 A Δ21 n i=1 n1 y i2 -10 log1 n i=1 n1 y i2
